div.head: MS I Drawings
div.p: Hand: pencil. In order of their appearance in MS I, front to back, the drawings contained in this Red Book are as follows:

list.item: [Plate 4, “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1] (probably p. 30 or p. 31);
“Heights of Wisdom, Depth of Fools” [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS I] (inside back endboard).

div.p: The first eleven drawings serve as “plates” to illustrate “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, in that the titles all refer to the characters. Few of the plates have a clear connection with the narrative, however. The drawing “Lucyʼs Hutch of Rabbits and Her Silkworms,” [Plate 3, “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1], for example, relates, not to its surrounding text, but to a discussion seventeen pages earlier; other plates reveal at best a conjectural relation to the text, wherever located in the story.

It is possible, therefore, that Ruskin may have drawn the plates independently of, and even prior to, producing the text to wrap around them. This is almost certainly what he did in “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2, in MS III (see, e.g., “Time: Blank Verse”). In MS I, a case might be made for Ruskinʼs effort to unify the frontispiece with the final poem in the Red Book, but even this decision could have been made on the fly (“Frontispiece,” [Plate] “1,” [“Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1]: Discussion).
